title: 110_hr5218
content: The "Fire-Safe Communities Act" is the short title of this legislation, which includes definitions for various terms. The "Fire-Safe Communities Act" defines key terms such as Administrator, Applicable model ordinance, Appropriate review panel, and Director. These definitions are crucial for understanding the legislation. The term "Director" refers to the Director of the National Institute of Standards and Technology. A "fire hazard area" is an area at significant risk from wildland fire as determined by the State forestry agency. A "fire-safe community" is a subdivision or municipality that has adopted local ordinances consistent with certain elements outlined in the legislation. A "municipality at risk" is a subdivision of a State located in a fire hazard area. Model ordinances for communities in fire hazard areas are outlined in Section 3. The Director will publish a Federal model ordinance for municipalities at risk within 18 months of this Act. The ordinance will include specifications for construction materials, guidelines for utilities and vegetation management, enforcement mechanisms for defensible space, and zoning standards for new residential construction in fire-prone areas. The Director will develop a Federal model ordinance for municipalities at risk, consulting with relevant authorities. The ordinance will cover water supplies, firefighting protection, road standards, building markings, and involve fire professionals in local protection models. The Director may consult with private entities and incorporate existing standards into the Federal model ordinance. States can adopt model ordinances based on the Federal guidelines. $7,500,000 is authorized for implementation. SEC. 4. FIRE MANAGEMENT ASSISTANCE GRANTS FOR FIRE-SAFE COMMUNITIES. The Administrator may modify the Fire Management Assistance Grant Program requirements for a municipality at risk, reducing the non-Federal share to 10 percent if significant progress is made in implementing a model ordinance. Rulemaking will define "significant progress" and establish procedures within 18 months of the Act's enactment. The term "Fire Management Assistance Grant Program" refers to the program under the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act. Procedures and requirements can be established to reduce the non-Federal share for the program. SEC. 5. GRANTS FOR RESPONSIBLE DEVELOPMENT. The Administrator shall provide grants to municipalities at risk to encourage responsible development in fire-prone regions and mitigate fire effects. Grants may be used for implementing local ordinances, educating on fire-resistant planning, enforcing construction requirements, and creating fire maps using GIS technology. The Administrator provides grants to municipalities for fire-safe practices and technology training. Grant awards are capped at $1,000,000, and applicants must meet matching fund requirements. Under this section, grants are awarded for fire-safe practices and technology training. Applications are reviewed by a panel, and grants must be spent within 3 years. $25,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2008 and beyond. Grants are provided for fire-hazard assessment maps. The Administrator provides grants to States for creating or updating fire-hazard assessment maps. Grants can be used for developing maps, conducting studies, and providing necessary resources. The maximum grant amount is $1,000,000, with a requirement for matching state funds. Applications for grants must be submitted as per the Administrator's requirements. The Administrator establishes a review panel to assess grant applications. Grants must be utilized within 3 years of award. $15,000,000 is authorized annually for this program. SEC. 7. Grants for community fire protection by the Forest Service and Department of the Interior. Grants by Department of the Interior under the Cooperative Forestry Assistance Act of 1978 are amended to include non-forested areas, rangelands, and local officials. Grants under the Cooperative Forestry Assistance Act of 1978 are expanded to cover non-forested areas, rangelands, and local officials. The Community and Private Land Fire Assistance Program is amended to enhance local government capacity for fire-resistant community and home design integration into local planning and ordinances. The Community and Private Land Fire Assistance Program is amended to enhance local government capacity for fire-resistant community and home design integration into local planning and ordinances. The Program will be administered by the Chief of the Forest Service and the Secretary of the Interior through State foresters or equivalent State officials. The amendment aims to establish a pilot program for fire-safe communities to coordinate across jurisdictional boundaries, allowing the Secretary and the Secretary of the Interior to assess the feasibility of providing assistance in this regard. The pilot program aims to provide grants for fire-safe communities near Federal land to prevent and manage fires. Grant funds can be used for implementing local ordinances and establishing cooperative fire agreements. The pilot program provides grants for fire-safe communities near Federal land to prevent and manage fires. Grant funds can be used for developing community wildfire protection plans, expanding education programs, implementing training programs for firefighters, and acquiring equipment for wildland fire preparedness. Recipients must provide non-Federal funds to match the grant amount. The pilot program requires recipients to provide 25 percent of the grant amount in non-Federal funds, with a waiver option in extraordinary circumstances.
